title-group.article-title: Integrative taxonomy of Thalerosphyrus Eatonı 1881 (Ephemeropteraı Heptageniidae) in Thailand

sec.p:
Integrative taxonomy of Thalerosphyrus Eatonı 1881
(Ephemeropteraı Heptageniidae ) in Thailand
Waranid Sutthacharoenthada , Michel Sartorib,c and Boonsatien Boonsoonga

aAnimal Systematics and Ecology Speciality Research Unit (ASESRU), Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Kasetsart University, Bangkok , Thailand ; bMuseum of Zoology, Palais de Rumine, Lausanne, Switzerland ; cDepartment of Ecology and Evolution, Lausanne University, Lausanne, Switzerland

body.p: ABSTRACT A comprehensive revision of the genus Thalerosphyrus in Thailand is assessed. Four species are recognised: T. flowersiıT. sinuosusıT. vietnamensis and one new species, Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov., which is described here. A morphological comparison of the described species is provided. A Maximum Likelihood (ML) consensus tree based on 658 bp of the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I (COI) gene of five species was performed. Uncorrected p-distances strongly support the identity of these species, originally based on morphology, and show differences of 8.4–29.8% between species and 1.4–6.3% within species.

http://www.zoobank.org/
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:pub:
850FB31C-2B6A-4AB2-92D5-3413B193F
196 ARTICLE HISTORY Received 17 October 2018 Accepted 14 August 2019KEYWORDSThalerosphyrus ; Heptageniidae ; COI; ThailandIntroduction
The Oriental genus Thalerosphyrus , established by Eaton (1881) , currently comprises seven valid species: T. bishopiBraasch and Soldán, 1986 from Malaysia ; T. determinatusWalker, 1853 from Java and Bali; T. flowersi Venkataraman and Sivamarakrishnan, 1987
from India ; T. lamuriensisSartori, 2014 from Sumatra; T. meghalaensis Selvakumar and Chandra, 2017
from India ; T. sinuosusNavás, 1933 from Java, Sumatra and Thailand and T. vietnamensisDang, 1967 from Vietnam .
In Thailand , the larvae of Thalerosphyrus are usually the dominant heptageniids in streams, together with those of Afronurus Lestage, 1924
. The larvae of T. sinuosus were reported to be widely distributed in Thailand and adjacent countries ( Boonsoong and Braasch 2013 ). However, a revision of Thalerosphyrus species in Southeast Asia has never been attempted. Here, we present an integrative approach, including morphological and barcoding analyses of Thalerosphyrus species currently found in Thailand .

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Thalerosphyrus larvae were collected by hand-picking specimens clinging to cobbles and boulders in slow-flowing water. Larvae were collected from 23 localities in Thailand ( Table 1 ). In total, 104 specimens were collected and examined. Most specimens were fixed and preserved in absolute ethanol for molecular and morphological studies. Twenty-two selected specimens were used for molecular analysis. Some parts were dissected under a stereomicroscope and mounted in Euparal solution for examination and photography. Pictures of specimens were performed with Visionary LK System (Dun, Inc., USA ), and microscopic structures were examined and photographed using a LEICA M205C. The final plates were processed using Adobe Photoshop CS6. Specimens are deposited in the Zoological Museum Kasetsart University ( ZMKU ), Bangkok , Thailand and Museum of Zoology ( MZL ), Lausanne, Switzerland .

For the molecular analysis, DNA was extracted using a Genomic DNA Purification Kit (NucleoSpin, Macherey-Nagel, Germany ) following the manufacturer’ s protocol. A fragment of the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I (COI) gene was amplified using the primers LCO1490 5 ʹ-GGT CAA CAA ATC ATA AAG ATA TTG G- 3 ʹ ) and HCO2198 (5 ʹ-TAA ACT TCA GGG TGA CCA AAA AAT CA- 3 ʹ ), designed by Folmer et al. (1994) . The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) conditions were as follows: a 50 μl final reaction volume containing 25 μl PCR Master Mix Solution ( i -Taq), 1 μl of each primer, 2 μl total DNA and 21 μl nuclease free sterile water. The PCR was performed as follows: 5 minutes at 94°C, 30 seconds at 94°C, 30 seconds at 48°C and 60 seconds at 72°C (40 cycles), with a final elongation step at 72°C for 10 minutes ( Gattolliat et al. 2015 ). The amplified products were separated by electrophoresis on a 1.2% agarose gel. Both DNA strands were purified and sequenced using the same primers by Macrogen Inc. ( South Korea ).

Sequences were edited and assembled using the Codon Code aligner (Codon Code Corporation, Dedham, MA) and aligned using Jalview ( Waterhouse et al. 2009 ). The best-fit models of nucleotide substitution, as judged by the Akaike information criterion (AIC), were estimated using MEGA 7. The best-fit evolution model obtained was T92+G. Species delineation was estimated based on maximum likelihood (ML). The ML analysis was performed with MEGA 7, using the Nearest-Neighbour-Interchange (NNI) method with 1000 bootstrap replicates. Pairwise (uncorrected-p) sequence distances were also calculated using the Kimura-2-parameter distance with the MEGA 7 program ( Kumar et al. 2016 ). Nucleotide sequences obtained in this study have been deposited in the GenBank database under the GenBank ID: MH109074 – MH109074 . Two published sequences from GenBank of T. sinuosus , three of T. lamuriensis and one of T. vietnamensis were also used in the reconstruction. Paegniodes sp. sequence from our own collection was selected as out-group.

sec.title: Abbreviations
sec.p: alt. – altitude; Prov. – province; leg. – collector (L. legulus collector); m – meter(s); Th . – Thalerosphyrus .

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 3.75 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galealacinia of the maxillae with ca. 16–20 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long, simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 7–9 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–6 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid, inner and outer margins clearly concave near apex (
(a)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded or truncate (
(a)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 7–11 arrow-shaped bristles in marginal and submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(a)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I, weakly developed on segment II, strongly developed on segment III and increasing in size up to VIII and subparallel to the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 1.5 times longer than wide (
(a)). Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth and numerous row of microdenticle rows (
(a)). Cerci whitish in the proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards the apex.
Materials examined

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum slightly expanded laterally, ca. 3.5 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca. 22–25 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 10–11 simple and fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 6–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave on their inner and outer margin near apex (
(b)).

Thorax. Pronotum slightly expanded laterally and posteriorly and basally fused to mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on dorsal surface of hind femora arrow shaped, clearly pointed (
(b)). Hind tibia with two rows of thin setae (
(a)) and a row of 7–8 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(b)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I, weakly developed on segment II, strongly developed on segment III and increasing size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(b)). Gill III–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical with inner concave margin near apex. Posterior margin of the tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(b)). Cerci whitish in proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing size towards apex.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 4.2 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galealacinia of the maxillae with ca.18–20 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 9–10 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long, simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave in their inner and outer margins near apex (
(c)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of the hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margins, apexes rounded or truncate (
(c)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 5–7 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(c)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I–II, weakly developed on segment III, strongly developed on segment IV and increasing in size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(c)). Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(c)). Cerci pale yellow with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards apex.
Materials examined

p.tp:material-citation: HOLOTYPE : mature nymph on slide, Soi Sawan waterfall , Ubon Ratchathani Prov. , 15.459933°N , 105.578350°E , alt. 267 m , 3-II-2017 , B. Boonsoong leg. ( ZMKU ).
1 larva (on slide), Sarika , Nakhon Nayok Prov ., 14.296194°N , 101.269583°E , alt. 20 m , 23-I-2016 , B. Boonsoong leg. ( ZMKU ).

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 3.8 times larger than long, with round apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long thin setae (
(a)). Maxilla with long, simple setae on inner margin of galea-lacinia and with fimbriate setae scattered on ventral surface. Basal segment of maxillary palp with rows of thin and simple setae on inner and outer margins; apical segment pointed, with rows of simple setae on outer margin. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca 16 combshaped setae (
(b)). Mandibles strongly bent in their distal part; lateral margins with several rows of long and thin setae; left mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 6 teeth; inner incisor bifid, bearing two seta-like; with 6 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor (
(c)). Right mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 8 teeth; inner incisor trifid; 9 fimbriate setae below incisors (
(d)). Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae replaces before the apex by small setae up to near the lower part of superlinguae (
(e)). Labium with glossae rhomboid, almost straight on their inner and outer margins near the apex (
(f)).

Thorax. Pronotum weakly expanded, not wider than the head and basally not fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b) & (5a–b)). Fore femora with submarginal row(s) of stout bristles on the inner and outer margins. Hind femora with submarginal row of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins and subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded (
(d)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae in marginal position (
(b)) and a row of 10–12 pointed bristles in the marginal or submarginal positions. Tarsal claw with 3 teeth (
(d)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansions not developed on segment I and II, weakly developed on segment III–IV, moderately developed on segment V and reaching their maximum size on segment VIII (
(c) & 5(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide. Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long (
(d)). Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth and a few microdenticle rows (
(d)). Cerci brownish red with medium brown bands increasing in size towards the apex. Paracercus whitish in the proximal part, with a dark brown band every 2–3 segments.
Etymology
The epithet is derived from the name of Thailand , referring to the type locality.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum slightly expanded laterally, ca. 3.5 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca. 22–25 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 10–11 simple and fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 6–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave on their inner and outer margin near apex (
(b)).

Thorax. Pronotum slightly expanded laterally and posteriorly and basally fused to mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on dorsal surface of hind femora arrow shaped, clearly pointed (
(b)). Hind tibia with two rows of thin setae (
(a)) and a row of 7–8 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(b)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I, weakly developed on segment II, strongly developed on segment III and increasing size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(b)). Gill III–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical with inner concave margin near apex. Posterior margin of the tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(b)). Cerci whitish in proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing size towards apex.
Materials examined

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 4.2 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galealacinia of the maxillae with ca.18–20 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 9–10 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long, simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave in their inner and outer margins near apex (
(c)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of the hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margins, apexes rounded or truncate (
(c)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 5–7 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(c)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I–II, weakly developed on segment III, strongly developed on segment IV and increasing in size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(c)). Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(c)). Cerci pale yellow with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards apex.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 3.8 times larger than long, with round apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long thin setae (
(a)). Maxilla with long, simple setae on inner margin of galea-lacinia and with fimbriate setae scattered on ventral surface. Basal segment of maxillary palp with rows of thin and simple setae on inner and outer margins; apical segment pointed, with rows of simple setae on outer margin. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca 16 combshaped setae (
(b)). Mandibles strongly bent in their distal part; lateral margins with several rows of long and thin setae; left mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 6 teeth; inner incisor bifid, bearing two seta-like; with 6 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor (
(c)). Right mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 8 teeth; inner incisor trifid; 9 fimbriate setae below incisors (
(d)). Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae replaces before the apex by small setae up to near the lower part of superlinguae (
(e)). Labium with glossae rhomboid, almost straight on their inner and outer margins near the apex (
(f)).

Thorax. Pronotum weakly expanded, not wider than the head and basally not fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b) & (5a–b)). Fore femora with submarginal row(s) of stout bristles on the inner and outer margins. Hind femora with submarginal row of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins and subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded (
(d)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae in marginal position (
(b)) and a row of 10–12 pointed bristles in the marginal or submarginal positions. Tarsal claw with 3 teeth (
(d)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansions not developed on segment I and II, weakly developed on segment III–IV, moderately developed on segment V and reaching their maximum size on segment VIII (
(c) & 5(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide. Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long (
(d)). Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth and a few microdenticle rows (
(d)). Cerci brownish red with medium brown bands increasing in size towards the apex. Paracercus whitish in the proximal part, with a dark brown band every 2–3 segments.
Etymology
The epithet is derived from the name of Thailand , referring to the type locality.

Left mandible with 7–9 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–6 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid, inner and outer margins clearly concave near apex (
(a)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded or truncate (
(a)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 7–11 arrow-shaped bristles in marginal and submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (

(a)). Cerci whitish in the proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards the apex.

Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 3.75 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galealacinia of the maxillae with ca. 16–20 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long, simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 7–9 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–6 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid, inner and outer margins clearly concave near apex (
(a)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded or truncate (
(a)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 7–11 arrow-shaped bristles in marginal and submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(a)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I, weakly developed on segment II, strongly developed on segment III and increasing in size up to VIII and subparallel to the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 1.5 times longer than wide (
(a)). Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth and numerous row of microdenticle rows (
(a)). Cerci whitish in the proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards the apex.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum slightly expanded laterally, ca. 3.5 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca. 22–25 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 10–11 simple and fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 6–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave on their inner and outer margin near apex (
(b)).

Thorax. Pronotum slightly expanded laterally and posteriorly and basally fused to mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on dorsal surface of hind femora arrow shaped, clearly pointed (
(b)). Hind tibia with two rows of thin setae (
(a)) and a row of 7–8 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(b)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I, weakly developed on segment II, strongly developed on segment III and increasing size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(b)). Gill III–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical with inner concave margin near apex. Posterior margin of the tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(b)). Cerci whitish in proximal part, with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing size towards apex.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 4.2 times larger than long, with rounded apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long and thin setae. Crown of the galealacinia of the maxillae with ca.18–20 comb-shaped setae. Right mandible with 7–8 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 5–7 long simple and thin setae below the mola. Left mandible with 9–10 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor and ca. 4–5 long, simple and thin setae below the mola. Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae up to the lower part of the superlinguae. Labium with glossae rhomboid slightly concave in their inner and outer margins near apex (
(c)).

Thorax. Pronotum greatly expanded laterally and posteriorly, and basally fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b)). Femora with submarginal rows of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins, increasing in numbers from the fore to the hind leg. Bristles on the dorsal surface of the hind femora with subparallel or slightly convergent margins, apexes rounded or truncate (
(c)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae and a row of 5–7 arrow-shaped bristles in the marginal or submarginal position. Tarsal claw with 3–4 teeth (
(c)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansion not developed on segment I–II, weakly developed on segment III, strongly developed on segment IV and increasing in size up to VIII and divergent with the body (
(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide (
(c)). Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long. Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth, and numerous microdenticle rows (
(c)). Cerci pale yellow with 3–4 dark brown bands increasing in size towards apex.
Materials examined

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Head. Labrum expanded laterally, ca. 3.8 times larger than long, with round apexes; dorsal surface and anterior margin covered with long thin setae (
(a)). Maxilla with long, simple setae on inner margin of galea-lacinia and with fimbriate setae scattered on ventral surface. Basal segment of maxillary palp with rows of thin and simple setae on inner and outer margins; apical segment pointed, with rows of simple setae on outer margin. Crown of the galea-lacinia of the maxillae with ca 16 combshaped setae (
(b)). Mandibles strongly bent in their distal part; lateral margins with several rows of long and thin setae; left mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 6 teeth; inner incisor bifid, bearing two seta-like; with 6 fimbriate setae below the inner incisor (
(c)). Right mandible with outer incisor serrate on inner margin, composed of ca. 8 teeth; inner incisor trifid; 9 fimbriate setae below incisors (
(d)). Hypopharynx with robust lingua bearing a tuft of small setae, superlinguae densely covered with long and thin setae replaces before the apex by small setae up to near the lower part of superlinguae (
(e)). Labium with glossae rhomboid, almost straight on their inner and outer margins near the apex (
(f)).

Thorax. Pronotum weakly expanded, not wider than the head and basally not fused to the mesonotum (
(a–b) & (5a–b)). Fore femora with submarginal row(s) of stout bristles on the inner and outer margins. Hind femora with submarginal row of pointed bristles on the inner and outer margins and subparallel or slightly convergent margin, apex rounded (
(d)). Hind tibia with one row of thin setae in marginal position (
(b)) and a row of 10–12 pointed bristles in the marginal or submarginal positions. Tarsal claw with 3 teeth (
(d)).

Abdomen. Posterolateral expansions not developed on segment I and II, weakly developed on segment III–IV, moderately developed on segment V and reaching their maximum size on segment VIII (
(c) & 5(c)). Gill I with asymmetrical elongated and rounded plate, 2 times longer than wide. Gill II–VI strongly asymmetrical, wider than long (
(d)). Gill VII oval and almost symmetrical. Posterior margin of tergites with irregularly pointed teeth and a few microdenticle rows (
(d)). Cerci brownish red with medium brown bands increasing in size towards the apex. Paracercus whitish in the proximal part, with a dark brown band every 2–3 segments.
Etymology
The epithet is derived from the name of Thailand , referring to the type locality.

sec.title: Molecular analysis
sec.p: The Maximum Likelihood (ML) reconstruction, which contained 22 specimens and 5 sequences of the mitochondrial COI gene (658 bp) from GenBank, is shown in Figure (12). The tree clearly show 3 principal clades. Clade 1 includes 2 species: T. thailandensis and T. flowersi , which can be found in north-eastern and northern Thailand , respectively. Clade 2 includes only T. lamuriensis from GenBank and clade 3 includes 2 species: T. vietnamensis , which is widely distributed, and T. sinuosus , which can be found only in southern Thailand . The uncorrected p-distances between the species found in Thailand are shown in Table 3 . The genetic distance within the same species ranged from 1.4% to 6.3%, whereas the differences between species ranged from 8.4% to 29.8%. The highest value of 29.8% was between T. thailandensis sp. nov. and T. lamuriensis , while the lowest value of 8.4% was between T. sinuosus and T. vietnamensis .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
This study shows that four species of Thalerosphyrus occur in Thailand ( T. flowersiı T. sinuosusı T. vietnamensis and T. thailandensis sp. nov. ). The larva of T. thailandensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from others Thalerosphyrus species by 1) state of development of posterolateral projection, 2) number of comb shape setae on the maxillae, 3) shape of glossae and 4) presence of few microdenticles on posterior margin of tergite IV. Comparison of larvae of all species is shown in
Table 2. T . thailandensis sp. nov. has moderately developed posterolateral projections on the abdomen (
(c) & 5(c)), whereas in T. flowersi they are always greatly enlarged, developed and parallel with the body (
(c)). In T. sinuosusı T. vietnamensis and T. lamuriensis these projections are also enlarged and developed but they are divergent with the body (
(c) & 3(c)). In contrast, T. determinatus and T. meghalayensis have weakly developed posterolateral projections. The number of comb-shaped setae on the maxillae of T. thailandensis sp. nov. is less numerous than in other species. Comparing the shape of glossae, their margins are almost straight in T. thailandensis sp. nov. (
(d)) whereas in other species their inner and outer margins near apex are concave (
(a–c)). T. thailandensis sp. nov. and T. lamuriensis show a few row of microdenticles on posterior margin of tergite IV (
(d)), which is not the case in other species(
(a–c)).
Figure 5.Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov. female larva. (a) Habitus in dorsal view. (b) Habitus in ventral view. (c) Detail of abdominal segments VI–IX in ventral view.
Figure 6. Labial glossa. (a) Thalerosphyrus flowersi (arrow show clearly concave near apex). (b) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus . (c) Thalerosphyrus vietnamensis . (d) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov.
Figure 7. Bristles on the dorsal face of the hind femur. (a) Thalerosphyrus flowersi . (b) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus . (c) Thalerosphyrus vietnamensis . (d) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov.
Figure 8. Outer margin of the hind tibia. (a) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus (arrow show two rows of setae). (b) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov. (arrow show one rows of setae).
Figure 9. Tarsal claw. (a) Thalerosphyrus flowersi . (b) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus . (c) Thalerosphyrus vietnamensis . (d) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov.

The larva of T. bishopi have been briefly described from Gombak River ( Malaysia ) by Braasch and Soldán (1986) . Unfortunately no specimens were available to us during this study. However, T. thailandensis sp. nov. seems to be easily separated from T. bishopi based on the posterolateral projection and number of combshaped setae on the maxillae ( Table 2 ).

The distribution of Thalerosphyrus in Thailand is shown in
. Boonsoong and Braasch (2013) reported that T. sinuosus is widely distributed in Thailand . Our present study indicates rather that it is T. vietnamensis which is widely distributed in Thailand . Although we investigated only one gene (COI) for species delimitation, which is commonly used in several studies ( Gattolliat et al. 2015 ; Tenchini et al. 2018 ), our molecular reconstruction strongly supports the species delimitation based on larval morphology. Comparison of the taxonomic characters revealed that T. sinuosusı T. vietnamensis and T. lamuriensis share the feature of having greatly developed and divergent posterolateral spines along the abdomen ( Sartori 2014 ). The ML tree placed these three species in the same clade. T. sinuosus has two rows of thin setae on the hind tibia as a unique character that makes it distinctly different from the other species ( Sartori 2014 ).
Figure 10. Gill I. (a) Thalerosphyrus flowersi . (b) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus . (c) Thalerosphyrus vietnamensis . (d) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov.

Figure 11. Posterior margin of the abdominal tergite IV. (a) Thalerosphyrus flowersi . (arrow show numerous row of microdenticles). (b) Thalerosphyrus sinuosus . (c) Thalerosphyrus vietnamensis . (d) Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov. (arrow show a few row of microdenticles).

Figure 12. Mouthpart of Thalerosphyrus thailandensis sp. nov. (a) Labrum. (b) Right maxilla in ventral view. (c) Enlargement of left mandible in ventral view. (d) Enlargement of right mandible in ventral view. (e) Hypopharynx. (f) Labium in ventral view.

The larvae of T. flowersi and T. thailandensis sp. nov. were placed in the same clade and they have posterolateral spines parallel with the body as shared characters. However, the posterolateral spines of T. flowersi are longer than those of T. thailandensis sp. nov. The gill I ratio of T. flowersi is only 1.5 times longer than wide, while that of T. thailandensis sp. nov. around 2 times longer than wide. In order to complete the revision of the genus Thalerosphyrus in Southeast Asia, a morphological redescription of T. bishopi together with the availability of COI sequences from Gombak River in Malaysia would be most welcome.
